posts.post_content:
He's tailor-made for EDH, and it shows. He is very, very good but does not seem broken in the format, like Animar does. He was clearly designed as a build-around card, but the good part is that what you can build around him is not so well-defined. You can run the token-deck route, the +1/+1 counter route, the heavy sacrifice/death trigger route, and probably a few others. Let's start by listing cards he is ridiculous with:  
[Sigil Captain](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Sigil Captain): All the Saprolings you can pay for and subsequently huge creatures.  
[Juniper Order Ranger](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Juniper Order Ranger): Al the Saprolings you can pay for, and no sacrificing before you get a huge creature  
[Vish Kal, Blood Arbiter](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Vish Kal, Blood Arbiter): Decent since you can pay ![Variable Colorless](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=X&type=symbol) to kill something with toughness X or less, Vish himself gets huge for cheap, nuts with Juniper Order Ranger and/or Sigil Captain. Potentially -4/-4 for ![1](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=1&type=symbol) if you've got both.  
[Skullclamp](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Skullclamp)/[Fecundity](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Fecundity): Hahahaha. Hahahaha! HAHAH... [(see all)](javascript:void(0);)
posts.html:
He's tailor-made for EDH, and it shows. He is very, very good but does not seem broken in the format, like Animar does. He was clearly designed as a build-around card, but the good part is that what you can build around him is not so well-defined. You can run the token-deck route, the +1/+1 counter route, the heavy sacrifice/death trigger route, and probably a few others. Let's start by listing cards he is ridiculous with:
Sigil Captain: All the Saprolings you can pay for and subsequently huge creatures.
Juniper Order Ranger: Al the Saprolings you can pay for, and no sacrificing before you get a huge creature
Vish Kal, Blood Arbiter: Decent since you can pay to kill something with toughness X or less, Vish himself gets huge for cheap, nuts with Juniper Order Ranger and/or Sigil Captain. Potentially -4/-4 for if you've got both.
Skullclamp/Fecundity: Hahahaha. Hahahaha! HAHAH... (see all)

posts.post_content: Out of all the Precon EDH general's, Ghave is by far my favorite. He's cheap, He boosts your creatures, and he gives you tokens. What's not to love? And because he's a big creepy looking guy, I decided to build around that theme. And what I got was an Infect EDH deck that Reanimates, Spawns, Kills, Life Gain, and literally sucks the life out of you as it grows in power. Just like a Diseased Fungus would do.
posts.html:

Think about this guy with [Sigil Captain](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Sigil Captain). 1: Make a 2/2, assuming you pull the 3/3's counter off to make another 3/3. No other cost. Or try it with [Doubling Season](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Doubling Season) too. 1: Make a 4/4 and a 5/5.  
  
The synergies with this guy are unfreakingbelievable. I cannot wait to finish building my deck.

posts.post_content:
To all people who don't see why this is three colours, I think I've got it figured out:  
  
He's Green, White and Black.  
  
He comes into play with five +1/+1 counters. This makes him big and symbolises growth. Which is green.  
  
He can remove counters from some creatures to create others. Those creatures sacrifice personal strength to contribute to the community, or the greater good. Which is white.  
  
He can sacrifice creatures to add to the strength of others. Which is black.
posts.html:

He can sacrifice creatures to add to the strength of others. Which is black.

posts.post_content:
I agree with GrimjawxRULES, if it said spore counters instead of +1/+1 counters it would be much cooler (although probably broken in its current state)  
  
Good yes, but not fungus cool/not really good with fungus decks, I am disappoint. All he can do is buff up your fungus, when I *from my own personal experiences* hate losing saps for any reason other than fungus abilities or protecting myself.  
  
If I added him to my fungus deck, or as an EDH commander in my EDH fungus deck,  
  
Ability one: completely worthless, other than himself, so what? He is 10 mana into 5 [Saproling](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Saproling)s? Lame  
  
Ability two: I can sack fungus, which is bad, they do more work the longer they are on the field, turning one into a 2 mana [Saproling](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Saproling) isn't a good investment, I'm probably losing if I have to do that. I could buff fungus or other [Saproling](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Saproling)s, but when they start at 1 power... there is a reason it's called [Sprout Swarm](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Sprout Swarm). Usually i... [(see all)](javascript:void(0);)

If I added him to my fungus deck, or as an EDH commander in my EDH fungus deck,

Ability one: completely worthless, other than himself, so what? He is 10 mana into 5 Saprolings? Lame

Ability two: I can sack fungus, which is bad, they do more work the longer they are on the field, turning one into a 2 mana Saproling isn't a good investment, I'm probably losing if I have to do that. posts.post_content:
Character Bio:  
When monsoons devastated the land of Drakkus, the herds drowned and the harvests washed away. The humans there were forced to the fungal forests to find sustenance, and find it they did—in the form of the mycoids and their saproling offspring. What the humans saw as salvation, the mycoids called genocide, and they declared war on the invading mammals. Mages tore through the sporeborn troops with fire and steel. Only when the mycoid hero Ghave, Guru of Spores emerged did the tide finally turn. Gifted with mystic influence over the sporeborn, Ghave sculpted the fungal matter of his people into an ever-mutating army and reclaimed his forest home.
posts.html:
Character Bio:
When monsoons devastated the land of Drakkus, the herds drowned and the harvests washed away. The humans there were forced to the fungal forests to find sustenance, and find it they did—in the form of the mycoids and their saproling offspring. What the humans saw as salvation, the mycoids called genocide, and they declared war on the invading mammals. Mages tore through the sporeborn troops with fire and steel. Only when the mycoid hero Ghave, Guru of Spores emerged did the tide finally turn. Gifted with mystic influence over the sporeborn, Ghave sculpted the fungal matter of his people into an ever-mutating army and reclaimed his forest home.

posts.post_content: This is sad, because I truly love this card. It appeals to every part of me as a magic player. In my commander deck he allows me to play GW. The colors that my personality has the most synergy with. Unfortunately, he is also highly outclassed by bleed decks. If someone you are playing against drops even a Blood Seeker then your entire deck becomes completely useless. 1B that reads "Win game." against the Fungus Shaman? It's enough to make me want to cry.
